# Draft:Hiberno-Scandinavian Wars

The Hiberno-Scandinavian Wars refers to a period of conflict between the Irish and Vikings (and later Norsemen) that took place from 795 to 1103. They started with the first Viking raid in Ireland in 795, and ended with the death of Magnus III of Norway in 1103.
Viking raids and battles in Ireland
795 to 840
In the year 795, Vikings attacked Rathlin Island. According to the Annals of Ulster, they burned down the island's buildings and sacked its church.
The Vikings would continue to commit nondescript raids from then forward.
840 to 902
In roughly 840, the Vikings seized territory on Ireland's west coast, and established a Longphort, in what is now Dublin. This marked a crucial moment in Irish history, as it was at this point the Vikings stopped simply raiding Ireland, but conquering and settling in it, founding Norse-Gaelic kingdoms.
From the 860s, a number of Irish revolts against the Vikings sprung up. In 902, the Vikings were expelled from the island.
917 to 1014
After returning from their expulsion, the Vikings took power once again. They would then start to engage the Irish in battles, such as Islandbridge in 919, Sulcoit in 968, Cathair Cuan in 977, Tara in 980, Glenmama in 999, and Clontarf in 1014.
The Battle of Clontarf led by the High King of Ireland, Brian Boru was the last major battle between the Irish and the Vikings. It resulted in victory for the Irish, and caused Viking power in Ireland to diminish severely. Viking figures such as Sigurd the stout and Brodir of Man died here.
Magnus Barefoot's Campaigns
Description
Magnus Olafsson, also known as Magnus Barefoot, was the King of Norway from 1093 to 1103. From 1098 until his death, he reestablished Norwegian control in former Viking-ruled places, such as The Isle of man, The Hebrides, and Dublin. He is considered by some to be the last true Viking king, though that title is usually given to Harald Sigurdsson.
Activity in Ireland
around the year 1100, Magnus sailed for Ireland, taking Dublin shortly after. In 1102, he made an alliance with the king of Munster and High King of Ireland, Muirchertach Ua Briain, by arranging a marriage between Muirchertach's daughter and Magnus' son.
Death
On the 24th of August 1103, Magnus was foraging for food in Ulster, when suddenly, He was killed by an Ulaid ambush. His death marked the end of the Hiberno-Scandinavian Wars, as it would be the last time any Norseman attempted to invade Ireland. He is buried in Downpatrick, County Down.
